An Extensive Commentary on the Profound Sūtra Unraveling the Intent

notesStmt.note: Jigme Damchö Gyatso ('jigs med dam chos rgya mtsho) describes Woncheuk’s commentary as having eight chapters: 1) Introduction; 2) The Character of the Ultimate Truth; 3) The Character of Mind, Sentience, and Consciousness; 4) The Characters of All Phenomena; 5) The Character of Naturelessness; 6) Revealing Yoga; 7) The Grounds and Perfections; and 8) Achieving the Activities of a One Gone Thus. According to Woncheuk, the second through fifth are what are to be analyzed; the sixth is the yogic path, and the last is the fruit to be attained. Jigme Damchö Gyatso reports that the second chapter of Woncheuk’s rendering corresponds to the first four chapters of the Tibetan translation of the sūtra and that the remainder of Woncheuk’s version corresponds to the fifth through tenth chapters of the Tibetan translation of the sūtra. Thus, the Tibetan version of the text has an introduction and ten chapters whereas Woncheuk’s has eight chapters with the introduction being counted as a chapter.
